abstract.text: A 2D physics body that is moved by a physics simulation.

inlineContent.text: implements full 2D physics. It cannot be controlled directly, instead, you must apply forces to it (gravity, impulses, etc.), and the physics simulation will calculate the resulting movement, rotation, react to collisions, and affect other physics bodies in its path.
The body’s behavior can be adjusted via
. By changing various properties of the object, such as
, you can control how the physics simulation acts on it.

A rigid body will always maintain its shape and size, even when forces are applied to it. It is useful for objects that can be interacted with in an environment, such as a tree that can be knocked over or a stack of crates that can be pushed around.
If you need to override the default physics behavior, you can write a custom force integration function. See
very often may lead to some unpredictable behaviors. If you need to directly affect the body, prefer
as it allows you to directly access the physics state.
This object emits the following signals:

abstract.text: Applies a positioned impulse to the body.
Applies a directional force without affecting rotation. A force is time dependent and meant to be applied every physics update.
Multiplies the gravity applied to the body. The body’s gravity is calculated from the
and/or any additional gravity vector applied by
, the body is frozen. Gravity and forces are not applied anymore.
Sets the body’s velocity on the given axis. The velocity in the given vector axis will be set as the given vector length. This is useful for jumping behavior.
Adds a constant directional force without affecting rotation that keeps being applied over time until cleared with
Emitted when the collision between one of this RigidBody2D’s
to be set high enough to detect all the collisions.
Defines the way the body’s center of mass is set. See
, the body cannot rotate. Gravity and forces only apply linear movement.
, the body will not move and will not calculate forces until woken up by another body through, for example, a collision, or by using the
The body’s total constant rotational forces applied during each physics update.
A 2D physics body that is moved by a physics simulation.
The body’s total constant positional forces applied during each physics update.
The body’s custom center of mass, relative to the body’s origin position, when
is set to .custom. This is the balanced point of the body, where applied forces only cause linear acceleration. Applying forces outside of the center of mass causes angular acceleration.
Types that conform to VariantRepresentable can be stored directly in
with no conversion.  These include all of the Variant types from Godot (for
SwiftGodot.Object) as well as the built-in Swift types UInt8, Int64 and Double.

to be set high enough to detect all the collisions.

Framework to write Godot Game Extensions using the Swift Programming Language.

The body’s moment of inertia. This is like mass, but for rotation: it determines how much torque it takes to rotate the body. The moment of inertia is usually computed automatically from the mass and the shapes, but this property allows you to set a custom value.

Applies a positioned force to the body. A force is time dependent and meant to be applied every physics update.
Returns the number of contacts this body has with other bodies. By default, this returns 0 unless bodies are configured to monitor contacts (see

, the RigidBody2D will emit signals when it collides with another body.
Emitted when the physics engine changes the body’s sleeping state.
Applies a rotational force without affecting position. A force is time dependent and meant to be applied every physics update.
The maximum number of contacts that will be recorded. Requires a value greater than 0 and
to start to register contacts. Use
to retrieve bodies that have been collided with.
Called during physics processing, allowing you to read and safely modify the simulation state for the object. By default, it is called before the standard force integration, but the
property allows you to disable the standard force integration and do fully custom force integration for a body.

The body’s linear velocity in pixels per second. Can be used sporadically, but
, because physics may run in another thread and runs at a different granularity. Use
as your process loop for precise control of the body state.
